dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, normally, when you think about a major financial crisis, you think, "Oh, we're good for a while, right?" Like, we just had one a decade ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, normally, when you think about a major financial crisis, you think, Oh, we're good for a while, right? Like, we just had one a decade ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Normally, one would say yes. The kind of full-blown systemic global financial crisis that erupted a decade ago is not like a typical septennial recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. Like, definitely not for another decade or two, at least. You'd think there'd be, um, some kind of breathing room.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. Like, definitely not for another decade or two, at least. You'd think there'd be, um, some kind of breathing room.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But wont it be another 20-40 years before the next big financial crisis, leaving plenty of time to get ready?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Because, uh, policymakers usually make reforms, and people just kinda forget over time. But this article we read, it really kinda says, "Nope, we don't live in normal times."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Because, uh, policymakers usually make reforms, and people just kinda forget over time. But this article we read, it really kinda says, Nope, we don't live in normal times.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The much lower frequency of systemic crises reflects two realities: policymakers respond with reforms to prevent their recurrence, and it normally takes investors, consumers, and politicians a long time to forget the last one. Unfortunately, we dont live in normal times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's not on autopilot anymore, is it? And what really struck me was, uh, it's not just about the central banks having excellent staff. It's the *entire* government that needs to be competent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's not on autopilot anymore, is it? And what really struck me was, uh, it's not just about the central banks having excellent staff. It's the entire government that needs to be competent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crisis management cannot be run on autopilot... The bad news is that crisis management involves the entire government, not just the monetary authority.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, like, Jay Powell and his team at the Fed? First-rate. But then it asks, who are the *other* adults in the room if a crisis hits?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, Jay Powell and his team at the Fed? First-rate. But then it asks, who are the other adults in the room if a crisis hits?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell and his team are first-rate, but who will be the other adults in the room if an externally generated financial crisis threatens?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And what if the next crisis isn't, you know, a carbon copy of 2008? What if it's, like, a massive cyberattack, or real interest rates suddenly spike and just rock fragile markets?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what if the next crisis isn't, you know, a carbon copy of two thousand eight? What if it's, like, a massive cyberattack, or real interest rates suddenly spike and just rock fragile markets?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But what if the next crisis is completely different, resulting from say, a severe cyberattack, or an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates, which rocks fragile markets for high-risk debt?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Can anyone honestly say certain administrations have the skill and experience to deal with *that* kind of totally new collapse?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Can anyone honestly say certain administrations have the skill and experience to deal with that kind of totally new collapse?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Can anyone honestly say that US President Donald Trumps administration has the skill and experience to deal with a major collapse?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the Fed's hands are, like, tied compared to 2008, because of Dodd-Frank. They can't just bail out private institutions as easily, even if the whole system is collapsing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the Fed's hands are, like, tied compared to two thousand eight, because of Dodd Frank. They can't just bail out private institutions as easily, even if the whole system is collapsing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, the Fed has less room for maneuver than it had in 2008, because the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reforms sharply restricted its ability to bail out private institutions, even if the entire system might otherwise collapse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Then you look at Europe. Populism, deep distrust, divisions, Brexit. The UK, for example. Can they really be expected to handle tough political decisions in a financial crisis?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then you look at Europe. Populism, deep distrust, divisions, Brexit. The U K, for example. Can they really be expected to handle tough political decisions in a financial crisis?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe has issues that are similar, or worse. With populism fueling deep distrust and divisions, financial resilience is almost certainly far lower than it was a decade ago. Just look at the United Kingdom, the other major global financial center, where the political elite have taken the country to the edge of the Brexit cliff. Can they really be expected to handle competently a financial crisis that requires tough political decisions and agile thinking?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just... it's a mess. But still, like, shouldn't we have, I don't know, twenty to forty years before the *next* big financial crisis? Isn't that the typical cycle?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just... it's a mess. But still, like, shouldn't we have, I don't know, twenty to forty years before the next big financial crisis? Isn't that the typical cycle?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But wont it be another 20-40 years before the next big financial crisis, leaving plenty of time to get ready?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what you'd hope, right? But the article points out a big issue: risks haven't disappeared. They've just kinda, uh, migrated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what you'd hope, right? But the article points out a big issue: risks haven't disappeared. They've just kinda, uh, migrated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even if regulations have been successful in containing risks to banks, it is likely that major sources of risk have simply migrated to the less regulated shadow financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: To the less regulated shadow financial system, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: To the less regulated shadow financial system, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it is likely that major sources of risk have simply migrated to the less regulated shadow financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And global debt is pushing, like, $200 trillion. So, yeah, maybe big banks look better on paper, but the risk is still very much out there, just in a different form.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And global debt is pushing, like, two hundred trillion dollars. So, yeah, maybe big banks look better on paper, but the risk is still very much out there, just in a different form.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What we know for sure is that the global financial system continues to expand, with global debt now pushing $200 trillion. Better financial regulation may have helped contain the corresponding growth in risk, but it is not necessarily shrinking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So all those reforms since 2008? Were they just... piecemeal, as the article calls them? Not enough?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So all those reforms since two thousand eight? Were they just... piecemeal, as the article calls them? Not enough?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the piecemeal reforms that have been enacted fall far short of what is most necessary

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They're improvements, sure, but not what's *really* necessary, like requiring banks to raise a larger share of their funding through equity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They're improvements, sure, but not what's really necessary, like requiring banks to raise a larger share of their funding through equity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the piecemeal reforms that have been enacted fall far short of what is most necessary: requiring banks to raise a larger share of their funding through equity issuance (or by reinvesting dividends), as economists Anat Admati of Stanford and Martin Hellwig of the Max Planck Institute have argued.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, an inexorably growing financial system combined with, um, an increasingly toxic political environment...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, an inexorably growing financial system combined with, um, an increasingly toxic political environment...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, an inexorably growing financial system, combined with an increasingly toxic political environment, means that the next major financial crisis may come sooner than you think.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Means the next major financial crisis, yeah, it could be way sooner than we think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Means the next major financial crisis, yeah, it could be way sooner than we think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, an inexorably growing financial system, combined with an increasingly toxic political environment, means that the next major financial crisis may come sooner than you think.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's, uh, that's not exactly comforting, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's, uh, that's not exactly comforting, is it?
